entry.title: Day 2 Shadows
entry.content:
Ok, so first let‚Äôs talk about the CSS box-shadow property that we‚Äôll be using:

box-shadow: none|h-shadow v-shadow blur spread color |inset|initial|inherit;
  • h-shadow and v-shadow are the positions of the horizontal and vertical shadows, respectively. They are in distance units (e.g. px).
  • blur is the blur distance. Larger values mean the shadow is more, well, blurred.
  • spread is the size of the shadow (with negative values allowed). It‚Äôs like the thickness of the shadow outline of the object. A negative value would mean that the shadow is smaller than the object.
  • No points for guessing what color is.
  • inset changes the shadow from an outer shadow (outset) to an inner shadow, if set.

As far as color goes, using a semi-transparent option seems to be the popular option ‚Äî and most readily simulates real shadows: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.4).

Let‚Äôs mess around with it abit:

<div style="
  box-shadow: 10px 5px 2px 3px rgba(0, 0, 0, .4); 
  width: 100px; height: 100px;"></div>

Ok, so if I wanted to create an effect like the one in the image below:

‚Ä¶ I know that:

  • The shadow has to be smaller than the object ‚Ä¶ so spread < 0
  • The shadow is centered, so the horizontal distance from the center of the object h_distance = 0px
  • Since the negative spread will cause the vertical distance to reduce to the center, we‚Äôll need to offset it by the same amount or slightly more (so it pokes out). That means v_distance >= spread

Which makes:

<div style="
  box-shadow: 0px 7px 5px -5px rgba(0,0,0,.4);
  width: 100px; height: 100px; background: #f7f7ca;"></div>

Not bad for such an early try!

Turns out, you can also set the box-shadow property multiple times to the same element (e.g. adding an inset shadow, and a regular one).

Back to buttons

In the previous post, we ended up with a button:

‚Ä¶ and wanted to add a shadow to it so it looks more realistic. We spoke briefly about lighting and how having a fixed light point on the page can help you decide how the gradients and shadows should look like.

Now, we‚Äôll try and put that to practice.

If we assume that the light source is in the top-left corner of the page, what should the shadow look like? My intuition is:

  • It‚Äôll be below the button (as opposed to above it üòÖ)
  • and slightly to the right so h_position > 0
  • with the shadow slightly larger than the button itself so spread > 0
  • no idea what blur should look like, so i‚Äôll try a bunch of stuff here

First attempt

<button style="
	box-shadow: 3px 2px 3px 2px rgba(0,0,0,.4);
	...

That looks way too forced. It‚Äôs screaming newbie! Let‚Äôs

  • soften the shadow (more blur, lower spread)
  • change the border to be slightly darker than the button

Second attempt

<button style="
	box-shadow: 2px 2px 4px 1px rgba(0,0,0,.4);
	...

Better, but still looks ‚Ä¶ off. I think it might help to add an inset shadow in there as well. While we‚Äôre at it, let‚Äôs also fix the border ‚Äî it looks too strong. Let‚Äôs give it a shot:

<button style="
  box-shadow: 2px 2px 4px 1px rgba(90,90,90,.4), 
              inset 0 0 5px 1px rgba(255,255,255,.1);
  background: linear-gradient(to bottom right, #f7b733, #fc4a1a);
  border: 1px solid rgba(252,74,26,.6);
  border-radius: 3px;color: #fff;padding: 10px 20px;">

Yup, that looks nicer still!

I did some searching and found this excellent image that sums up how elevation affects the shadow of an object (in terms of size and blur):

That‚Äôs it for now! I‚Äôll dig into this more in future posts, but this is quite nice for such an early try :)

Next‚Ä¶

  • Hover state shadows, etc
entry.summary: Today, we look at shadows and page lighting. You know how some shadows look amazing and others just look forced. Hopefully, we'll figure out how to make the former.

entry.title: Day 1 Gradients
entry.content:
Ok, so I‚Äôm pretty familiar with how to make a button:

<button style="background: #cfcfcf;">Hi there!</button>

Preview:

Ok, but that‚Äôs plain boring. Let‚Äôs add some juicy gradient goodness to the mix!

Gradient backgrounds

Gradients are most often used with the background CSS property, and there are two types:

  • Linear Gradient
  • Radial Gradient (I‚Äôll cover this later)

Linear gradient is the popular kid on the block, and it‚Äôs defined like so:

background: linear-gradient(direction, color-stop1, color-stop2, ...);

Ok, let‚Äôs try that on our button:

<button style="background: linear-gradient(to bottom, red, blue);">Hi there!</button>

Ah, that‚Äôs looking better.

I mean, sorta. It still looks horrendous (when you consider the actual colors). I think having subtle gradients would work better, I found a website that showcases some good looking gradients here.

Let‚Äôs take one example ‚Ä¶ OrangeFun:

<button style="
  background: linear-gradient(to bottom, #fc4a1a, #f7b733);">Hi there!</button>

Oh, that looks sweet ‚Äî but why? What‚Äôs the right amount of ‚Äúdistance‚Äù between colors so it turns out OK? I plugged the two colors into Photoshop to see how they differed:

Hmm, it seems that the primary difference is in that H value (‚ÄúHue‚Äù), with a difference of about ~30¬∞. Nice. That‚Äôs probably a good benchmark to consider when picking colors for a gradient combo.

Lesson: Vary Hue (up to 30¬∞) to get a good color combo for a gradient.

Finally, let‚Äôs add abit more CSS to make the thing look nice and polished:

<button style="
  background: linear-gradient(to bottom right, #f7b733, #fc4a1a);
  border: 1px solid #f7b733;
  border-radius: 3px;
  color: #fff;
  padding: 10px 20px;">Hi there!</button>

Ah, that looks lovely! Giving it a bit of breathing space (using padding) and a border with the lighter of the two shades looks great.

When using a gradient, use the lighter shade as the border

Also, I changed the direction of the gradient so it looks like the light is coming from the top left. I remember reading something about that somewhere, and will make tomorrow‚Äôs post about diving into lighting and shadows and all that goodness!

Stay tuned.

Next‚Ä¶

  • Radial gradients
  • Lighting, shadows
